intro: Alpinia novae-pommeraniae, commonly known as the New Pommerania ginger, is a perennial herb native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Zingiberaceae family, which includes other economically important plants like ginger and turmeric. The plant is characterized by its tall, erect stem and broad, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a waxy cuticle. Its inflorescence consists of clustered, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink, adding ornamental value to gardens. The rhizomes of Alpinia novae-pommeraniae are also used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits.
